context: Reinforcement Learning with Evolving Rubrics (RLER) enables training of deep research models for long-form tasks, outperforming existing models and proprietary systems while being more cost-effective. Deep research modelsperform multi-step research to produce long-form, well-attributed answers. However, most opendeep research modelsare trained on easily verifiable short-form QA tasks viareinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR), which does not extend to realistic long-form tasks. We address this withReinforcement Learning with Evolving Rubrics (RLER), in which we construct and maintain rubrics that co-evolve with the policy model during training; this allows the rubrics to incorporate information that the model has newly explored and to provide discriminative, on-policy feedback. Using RLER, we developDeep Research Tulu (DR Tulu-8B), the first open model that is directly trained for open-ended,long-form deep research. Across fourlong-form deep researchbenchmarks in science, healthcare and general domains, DR Tulu substantially outperforms existing opendeep research models, and matches or exceeds proprietary deep research systems, while being significantly smaller and cheaper per query. To facilitate future research, we release all data, models, and code, including our newMCP-based agent infrastructurefor deep research systems.
